Description: Body sherd of Chian Wild Goat Style pottery lid; interior reserved; exterior, white slip: two friezes of goats all to right, those above perhaps with heads turned back, those below grazing, separated by dilute line: of upper frieze only front legs of one goat and one rear leg of another preserved, with elaborate rosette, rising triangle and roundel as filling ornaments; of lower frieze body with red dots, head and antlers of one goat, lower body with red dots and reserved underbelly of second goat); dot rosettes, rising triangle and roundel as filling ornament; ancient repair hole near top right break.
Producer name: Attributed to: Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Royal Museum of Art and History, Brussels. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Also published in W. Schiering, Werkstätten orientalischer Keramik auf Rhodos (1957), 125, no. 329, 138, no. 719. Lemos describes the sherd as produced by the Painter of the Aphrodite Bowl because the decorative style is similarity in style to that bowl (Lemos 1991, 73-4).
Bibliographic references: CVA Brussels III / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Belgique (p. 1-2, no. 2, pl. 2)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 74, p. 253, no. 412, pl. 56)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.2163) (phase 2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Musées Royaux d’Art et d’Histoire, Brussels
Acquisition notes: Purchased in Cairo by M. Jean de Mot
